title: I Quit smoking Cigarette's and I feel weak
content: Hey,  I have a problem I believe only a Doctor can solve.  Anyway to the problem, I'm a 23 yr old male and I have just recently quit smoking cigarettes of 8-10 yrs, I usually  smoke a pack and a half a day more or less. I have gone 2 months with out smoking and I'm done Forever! So, I have been working out and I can't do as much push ups as I use to and I feel like I'm heavier I usually was able to do 40-50 when I was smoking and I usually did 2 -3 reps of  push ups  now I'm to 30 push ups and I feel I'm at muscle failure  ( muscle failure- when I can't possibly lift anymore or my body wont respond right to put it short my muscle will feel like rubber and I can't possibly do anymore push ups after only 30... )this also happens when I shadow box. when I was smoking I could shadow box for about 20-30 mins without muscle failure now its like 10-15 mins and I'm at muscle failure . this is very frustrating it's almost like trying to run a 100 yard dash with 2 sleeping feet I just keep trying and trying but can't go any further. I'm worried about this seeing I need to work out because I'm training to become a athlete and I really need to get in shape and train. Is their anything I can do? is their something wrong with my muscle's? or are they going through some kind of nicotine withdrawal? I don't know but it's getting to the point of concern and I can't just go through 30 push up's and expect to be in tip top shape or expect to succeed in the training I'm going to have to go through with my mighty 30 push ups. Also I have been jogging  for about 20 mins a day I feel there is nothing wrong there seeing I am getting slightly better my lungs are opening up and I'm running longer. but the week after I quit I tried to jog/sprint ( lasted for 15 mins)  and I had the same problem my body felt really weak and my legs were almost at muscle failure.   So yea if there is anything I can do to better this problem please inform me.  If you need me to explain a little better please feel free to tell me.  Thank you for any help I get.

author: Faye Lang, RN, MSW  Nurse Posts: 468 Joined: Thu Oct 30, 2008 7:01 pm Gender: Female Location: California
title: Re: I Quit smoking Cigarette's and I feel weak
content: Hi Jaime23,  Congratulations on stopping smoking!  What you are experiencing is most likely related to the "healing crisis" of stopping the influx of nicotine and tars into your body.  One pack of cigarettes per day deposits about one cup of tar and other residues into your lungs, and affects every system in your body.  Your body is reversing the effects of 8 to 10 years of smoking.  Symptoms that occur when a person stops smoking extend beyond removing nicotine from the body - that takes about a week.  But the repair and readjustment take longer, on average 2 or 3 months, but it can take less time or more time, depending on the individual and the amount smoked.  These symptoms include headaches or a general heaviness, nausea, sore throat, shaking, sweating, feeling cold, fatigue, increased appetite, problems with concentration, persistent cough (your lungs are ridding themselves of the accummulated tars and residues), runny nose, wheezing, shortness of breath, insomnia, indigestion and/or stomach pain, muscle aches and weakness, pain - stomach cramps, sore gums, pains in chest, pain in arms and legs, or pain anywhere!  There may also be mild depression or sadness, anxiety, boredome and loneliness, anger or irritability, since there are no longer cigarettes available to fill certain psychological needs.  Your symptoms appear to fall within those listed above, and will likely resolve with time, as you are already noticing with your lung capacity.  If they persist or increase, then it would be a good idea to have a doctor check your overall status.  If you have further questions, please feel free to ask.  Good luck to you!!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Foot falls asleep while walking/running
content: Hello, You have done the first thing I would recommend - check your footwear.  I would also have a podiatrist or foot specialist examine the foot for pes planus or pes cavus (low or high arch).  Foot abnormalities can affect everything biomechanically during running (from foot to knee to hip to low back).   The other consideration is the lumbar spine.  A pinched nerve in the lumbar spine can cause foot numbness.  With the high impact of running (all the way up to the spine) and if you have any history of back problems, the back should be checked.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

title: chronic calf strains(?) playing basketball
content: Hello,  I've been playing basketball for years and only over the past 2+ years have experienced these strains/pulls.  They start by feeling like cramps or charlie horses in either calf, top or bottom.  They have resulted in tears at least twice (bruising at the heel) – not sure if by overstretching or use.  I used to overstretch when I felt the first twinges, as well as afterwards.  I was told that when I tear the muscle, the stretching hinders the recovery, as it pulls apart the cartiledge.    I use neoprene + velcro wraps when I play.  I think I used to tighten them too much, which I no longer do.  I am fairly flexible and in fairly good shape for my age (43).  Thank You, Hawk941

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: chronic calf strains(?) playing basketball
content: Hi,  Basket ball injuries may be classified as - Sprains (mainly involve the ankle),  - Overuse injuries (Achilles tendinitis,patellar tendinitis) and  - Traumatic injuries.  Muscle pulls or tears (a type of traumatic injury) in basketball players occur primarily in the large muscles of the legs (gasrtocnemius and soleus). Your injury perhaps belongs to this type. Stretching  the thighs and calf muscles well and doing  warm-up exercises before playing helps to prevent them.  It is not advisable to do stretch the muscles in the acute phase following the injury.This will only cause more damage and fibrosis and delay recovery. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Lump under the skin of the right nipple
content: Hi,  Benign processes that may affect the nipple-areolar complex include cysts,adenomas, papillomas, leiomyomas, duct ectasia, periductal mastitis, and abscesses.  You say that you were on some muscle enhancer-which makes it likely to be hormone- related.The following possibilities need to be considered...  a) The nodule that you are describing could be an enlarged Montgomery's tubercle(usually enlarges in women during pregnancy and lactation).This is due to an imbalance of the male/female sex hormones- which can theoratically at least cause an enlargement of the Montgomery's tubercle(whether these tubercles exist in males is disputed).  b) Hyperkeratosis of the nipple and areola is a rare dermatologic disorder characterized by asymptomatic, hyperpigmented and verrucous hyperkeratosis (could be 'nevoid' as well). Occurs more often in young women and in men under estrogen treatment, suggesting an underlying hormonal influence. The condition is usually refractory to  keratolytics, retinoids, & topical steroids.  In your instance, the probability of hyperkeratosis of the nipple is very likely. You should consult a dermatologist or a surgeon first. It is very likely that a biopsy may be needed. Best wishes!

title: growth/knot on upper back from squats?
content: I recently (last year) have incorporated heavy squats into my training program. Within in the last 6 months I have noticed a hard growth/knot forming where I rest the bar. The growth is about the size of half of a mans fist in a perfect oval form.I have no pain or discomfort in the area, it just looks sort of awkward. I went to a plastic surgeon and he thought it was a lipoma due to the shape and feel. He tried to remove it through liposuction but failed because he discovered it was a "solid mass of some sort." He then cut a piece of it off and sent it in for a biopsy. Any ideas what this could be? I am almost certain it is from my bar placement and cannot be harmful. Thanks.
posted_time: Post  by ray36 » Mon Nov 09, 2009 11:15 am

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: growth/knot on upper back from squats?
content: Hi, If it happens to be a lipoma, it would be perhaps by chance. Your description makes it very likely that it is in some way related to the chronic weight-bearing.  Localized pressures over a period of time could cause 'callosities'.Consistency of these callosities is highly variable.Some of these could be soft like a lipoma and others could be firmer or even hard.  In some instances, if the chronic pressure happens to be localized to an area of a known 'bursa', it can inflamme and enlarge a bursa -- 'bursitis'.  One other possibility is localized trauma causing a hematoma (soft to begin with and later firmer due to 'organization').  The biopsy result will no doubt reveal its true nature. Best wishes!

After 6 months the contractures have not gone away. Any ideas/help would be greatly appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by summervillebuck » Wed Dec 09, 2009 8:51 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Right pectoral muscle contractures while walking
content: Hi, Spasms of pectoral muscles are well known. Some of which are explicable (those reported following sub-pectoral breast implants).Botox injections have been tried for this condition.  The pectoralis major muscle arises partly from the sternum.A coronary bypass surgery involves 'sternotomy' (division of the sternum).This is often closed at the end of the procedure using stainless steel wires.  There is no authentic explanation that i can offer for the spasms that you are experiencing. One may extrapolate the 'sub-pectoral implants' model and postulate that there is at-least a remote possibility It may be due to the irritation of the pectoralis major muscle caused by the wires.  'Secondary skeletal muscle spasm' is a term used by some for these types of spasms.  In patients who experience these spasms, it is a priority to exclude anginal pain or MI. Best wishes!

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Pulled chest , next steps unknown.
content: Hello, This sounds like a pectoralis major strain/sprain.  Treatment is rest, ice and NSAIDS for 48-72 hours.  Switch to heat and gentle stretching after 72 hours.  After 1-2 weeks the muscle may be ready for light (light) weight training.  Gradual return to full weight routine will take 4-6 weeks minimum.  Take care.

author: ZWillie1  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sat Aug 01, 2009 11:25 am Gender: Male
title: Costochondritis treatment?
content: I have had to deal with what I believe to be costochondritis, inflammation of where the ribs connect to the sternum, for half a year now. The injury occured as a result of overuse in weightlifting.  It started as acute pain that spread from the diaphragm back to the shoulder blade, though a week of rest saw it disappear.  After lifting weights a couple of times the next week, it flared up again, and I had to wait longer for the pain to alleviate.  The third time I aggravated it, it stuck with me for good, and has been constantly sore ever since.  Almost every time I sneeze, my chest cracks painfully and audibly, which aggravates it further.    I have been to told to rest (I've done so ad nauseam) and that I will probably "grow out of it". Unlikely considering that I am 16 and haven't grown an inch since 11.  Been shaving since 13.  I'd like to know if any treatment options exist that I'm unaware of, and also if there are any upper-body exercises that can be done with the condition.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Sprained ankle not healing
content: Hello, The bruising is normal.  In fact the bruising should darken a bit with time and gradually the blood from the broken blood vessels will be reabsorbed into the circulation. The tingling may be a sign that you are taxing the ankle too much.  Ease up on the weight bearing a bit; elevate and wrap the ankle to control swelling; include ice packs.  Over time the ankle will heal but will take several weeks.  One week is still considered the acute stage and needs an "easy does it" approach.  Take care.

posted_time: Post  by Willyboy » Thu May 28, 2009 7:40 am

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Little Leaguers Elbow
content: Hello, The hitting motion is less stressful on the medial elbow than during the pitching motion so hitting has less potential to aggravate the healing tissue (assuming he throws and bats the same side...if he throws right handed but bats left handed, hitting should put very little strain on the elbow).  I would suggest resting a day or two between pitching practice.  Pitching should be only practice (as you have stated) for a couple of weeks.  Again the time frame depends on the amount of soreness and the time to recover.  At this stage of his baseball life, erring on the side of caution is best.  Give him plenty of time to heal and gradually regain his strength and gradual return to competitive pitching.   When baseball season is over, remember to condition during the off season not only arm and shoulders but also legs.  Jim Palmer and Tom Seaver both Hall of Famers were known for their incredible leg strength and both were outstanding pitchers.  They both included long distance running in their work outs.  Take care and let me know how it goes.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Pain in calf while jogging
content: Hello, Unilateral calf pain that increases from jogging but not walking and swells and is sore with history of varicose veins. Worse case scenario is there is a blood clot in the calf however this would be unlikely with your activity level.  If a blood clot, it would be more likely be superficial and poses a very little risk of breaking off and going to the lung.  So a visit to a physician may be in order to check the leg.   The other consideration is a pulled muscle.  This is more likely.  Treatment includes ice, NSAIDS, rest, gentle stretching, gradual return to activity, general lower extremity strengthening.  As a runner, it is important to cross train - swimming, biking, eliptical machine, etc.  This works and balances other muscles which get neglected during straight running and will improve your overall health and lower risk of injury.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: cost of surgery no insurance
content: Hello, The triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) is a group of ligament which help support the wrist.  If this ligament tears, the wrist joint can become unstable not allow proper use of the hand and wrist.  So surgical repair when indicated should after rehabilitation give you a better chance at returning to work than if you did not have the surgery.  The same principle applies to the thumb tendon graft.   There may be some concern about healing of the TFCC or the outcome of the surgery if the ulna is naturally too long and bears more weight than its normal 20% with the carpal bones (the radius bears most of the weight with the carpal bones 80%).  This is fairly detailed information but in general, you will want to discuss as many details as possible with the surgeon before proceeding.   Lastly, you may want to discus the rehab process with the physical therapist before you have the surgery to know what to expect.  The surgery is only part of the solution, the rehab after surgery is the other important consideration.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Prohormone use in teens
content: Hello, Prohormones are precursors to other hormones like cortisol, testosterone and estrogen.  Some common prohormones would be pregnenolone and DHEA.   If I were to recommend DHEA or pregnenolone, it would be for a specific medical condition eg PMS, menopausal symptoms, low testesterone, or perhaps chronic fatigue.  I would also check both the end hormone and the prehormone levels.  Lastly, I would recommend hormone replacement products from a trusted and proven manufacturer.  From a supplement standpoint, it is imperative to buy any supplement from a manufacturer who is proven to provide supplements that are 100% natural and free from chemical processing.  When natural products are processed incorrectly, the chemical makeup and its effect can change and increase the risk of unwanted side effects.  I say this because both DHEA and pregnenolone are available in the U.S. without prescription.    I would not use anabolic steroids for muscle building.  Sexual side effects (gynecomastia, testicle atrophy etc) may be irreversible not to mention the potential side effects on the cardiovascular system.  Take care and let us know if you have any other questions.

title: Re: Falling off a Horse
content: Hello, Thanks for writing in and sorry to hear about the fall. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: swollen ankels low blood pressure
content: Hello, Swollen ankles can mean many things.  It can stem from problems in different systems of the body.  To name a few: kidney: loss of protein through the kidneys can increase edema in the legs liver: a decrease in liver function can cause leg edema heart: poor heart function (e.g. congestive heart failure) can cause leg swelling leg veins (circulatory system): varicose veins or inflammation of the venous system can cause leg swelling. musculoskeletal: arthritis in joints, inflammation in tendons, fractures can all cause localized pain in the lower limb.   It would be a good time to see you family physician who can take a complete physical and do an examination of the above system based on your story and determine which is most likely to cause the ankle swelling.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: anabolic steroids / gynocomastia
content: Hello, Adverse sexual side effects of anabolic steroids include gynecomastia (breast enlargement).  This is due to testosterone conversion to estradiol a hormone which in excess can enlarge breast tissue.  Generally speaking, the sexual side effects from anabolic steroid use may be irreversible.  Therefore any education on steroid use in athletes should include this statement.  Other sexual effects include risk of prostate cancer, decreasing testicle size, decrease sperm counts, and pain in the scrotum.    Regarding medicine, a selective estrogen receptor modifier (SERM) may help reduce breast tissue size by competing for the estrogen receptors in the breast thus blocking the effect of the increase in estrodiol from the anabolic steroid.  You would need to discuss this with your family physician who can prescribe and monitor the medicine.  Take care.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Sheath around my Shin Muscle ripped many years ago
content: Hello, The limbs both upper and lower are compartmentalized by fascia (thick fibrous tissue which separates muscle).  Within the compartments are blood vessels, nerves and muscles. Other types of fascia encases muscle to make it move and slide easily under the skin. I take it that the area is to the outside of the shin bone (lateral).  This would be the anterior tibialis muscle.  The muscle is probable unconditioned so will require 6-8 weeks of strengthening before doing any regular running. The best way to strengthen the muscle is to walk on your heels.  Use some caution not to cause swelling or pain.  An easier exercise is to place a small weight on the forefoot and lift the forefoot off the floor keeping the heel on the floor.  For inflammation, use ice, compression and NSAID.  The compression is key especially when exercising and eventually when running.  For some time, you probably need some type of compressive wrap to support the muscle since the fascia has been damaged.  There are some neoprene shin splints sleeves which can be helpful or simply an ACE wrap.  Let us know how it goes.

content: I sprained my MCL four months ago.  Physio has helped increase my overall muscle strength (leg and hip) and I have a near-full range of motion again.  However, my knee is still tender. content: Hello, Sounds like you had a release of the ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel.  And now decreased use of the left arm including frozen shoulder.  There is hope. author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: weird sound due to leg contusion
content: Hello,  The limb muscles and neurovascular structures are compartmentalized.  In the lower leg, the anterior tib is located in the anterior compartment and the peroneus muscles are contained in the lateral compartment. This sounds more like an anterior compartment problem.   Could the fascia between the two compartments be torn and allowing a lateral muscle to ride over ant tib or vice versa?  Very unlikely but worth having the orthopedist evaluate the leg.  Take care and let us know how it goes.

title: Re: weight lifting shoulder injury
content: Hello, You may be suffering from tendonitis in the shoulder - pectoralis major or supraspinatus or long head of the biceps. title: Brain Fog caused by, or made much worse by exercise
content: I am 51, male, 230 pounds, but (until recently) jogged 4 miles / day. Beginning 8-10 months ago, I began to be more disoriented than usual after exercise, and if I did more than an hour, I would notice a slight disorientation that would last for a day or two. This condition has gotten somewhat worse since then. My Doctor prescribed NAC and Folic acid. He said normally he would suggest increasing exercise for "Brain Fog", so he does not know how to approach this. The condition gets worse, then improves, gets worse, then improves....  Every place I have read about this seems to indicate exercise should improve this, and it helps if I do it every day without fail for about 30-45 minutes, any extra seems to make it bad for days! If I don't exercise at all, it stays at a low level, but does not go away. This "brain fog" causes me to forget names and words I should remember, makes me feel EXACTLY like I do after over-eating a turkey dinner on Thanksgiving, or like I'm slightly drunk all the time. It makes it more difficult to talk to others, it requires more focus than it should. It does not seem to affect my Sudoku puzzle skills.  I quit smoking about 2 years ago. Lungs feel better. I do have sinus trouble at times (allergies). My blood oxygen level is OK. Testosterone is 320. Blood tests showed nothing unusual except high trigycerides. Chocolate seems to make it worse. Eating a large meal makes it worse. MSG makes it worse. I have, some years back, worked in a high copper environment, which caused dry skin on the hands. I do not have excess tiredness that many associate with brain fog.  I did manage to eliminate the condition, largely, for 6-8 weeks with constant moderate exercise, taking herbal "anti-fungal" tablets, hydrogen peroxide therapy, and nano-silver, and high doses of crystal vitamin C. I don't know which, if any, worked. I stopped taking all three (still taking the C), and it seems to be returning.  I'd like your take on this. My doctor suggested perhaps a neurologist, but this sounds like the beginning of a search that could be frustrating. I have rarely been sick or ill, and I don't imagine myself sick.  Any ideas?

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: possible mid-back muscle pull, should i see a doctor?
content: Hello, Worsening back pain would be an indication to see a physician.  This is probably nothing more than strained muscles or ligaments but using prescription pain meds or muscle relaxers may help relieve symptoms in the short term.   Most acute back pain resolves within 4 weeks regardless of treatment (PT, chiropractor, exercise) however studies have shown that bed rest may cause secondary symptoms of muscle weakness and eventual worsening pain so the recommendation is activity as tolerated. Also, the physician should test the nerve status (sensory check, deep tendon relexes, limb strength, and straight leg raise test). Let us know how it goes and write back if there are any questions.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Severe Ankle Sprain Recovery
content: Hello, Thank you for writing in.  You have reported ankle sprain 10 months ago with residual swelling.  All other aspects of the ankle are back to normal.  What to make or to do about the swelling.  Swelling is usually the last symptom to leave in a lower limb injury or post operative condition.  So this is not uncommon especially.  The swelling may come and go over the next 6 months.  As long as the ankle is not "tweeked" (minor trauma), the swelling should gradually vanish.    To treat the swelling, do retro grade massage and use a compression garment (eg neoprene sleeve).  Of course elevation, active motion, and ice are indicated too.  Keep us posted and take care.

I asked him what are the treatments that I could use. He suggested that I quit sports for about a year or so and get physiotherapy. posted_time: Post  by Tagerinator » Sat Dec 27, 2008 11:08 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Osgood-Schlatter disease problems
content: Hello, Osgood Schlatter disease is a condition where the patella tendon pulls excessively on the tibia tubercle (point of its attachment) causing inflammation and a hard bump.  The bump is bony and again is caused by repetitive stress on the tendon's attachment site.  Sometimes the bump can avulse or separate from the bone - not common but can occur. Osgood Schlatter occurs in adolescents because the bones grow faster than the tendon and the tendon does not have time to elongate and adds stress to its insertion. Sports usually worsens the condition because of the demands placed on the quadriceps muscle and its patellar tendon. Treatment includes ice, NSAIDS, proper rest, stretching and strengthening exercise.  A physiotherapist can help with rehab. Whether you play hockey or other sports will depend on the degree of inflammation and the response to rehab.   Use of a patella strap may help. Take care and let us know how things go.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: not a side-stitch, but abdominal pain while running
content: Hello, Gall bladder inflammation or pain from a blocked bile duct can cause right upper quadrant pain and nausea/vomiting.  The symptoms usually proceed 30 minutes or so after meal especially fatty food.  If the gall bladder is infected or gangrenous then fever may occur along with increase belly pain and nausea/vomiting.  It would be worthwhile seeing your family physician to take your history and do a physical exam to find an accurate diagnosis.  A chest xray or other imaging of the abdomen (US or CT scan) may help with diagnosis.    Also check your leg lengths and check for scoliosis of the spine.  Both could cause pain in the thoracic rib cage area.  Take care and keep us posted.

title: What are the health effects of losing weight for wrestling?
content: What are the adverse health effects of losing drastic amounts of weight rapidly in order to make a certain weight class for wrestling
posted_time: Post  by jaymac91 » Mon Jan 12, 2009 6:12 pm

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: What are the health effects of losing weight for wrestling?
content: Hello, Most the weight lost quickly in wrestlers is water weight.  The risk is dehydration and organ damage (eg kidney).  Performing in athletics with dehydration is dangerous and the body can not regulate its temperature well and unable to supply the needed blood to muscles and internal organs.  Loosing water weight quickly in order to wrestle in a certain weight class is not wise and may lead to serious health problems.  Take care and stay healthy.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: I stoped smoking, what can i expect in my run times?
content: First, congratulations  on stopping smoking. You'll not only see some improvement in your run times, but you've extended your lifespan and improved your future health prospects incalculably. Now then...  Anwering your questions in order:  1) This is near-impossible to know. Much depends on how much the smoking was affecting  your performance before you quit. Then comes the question of how fast your lungs will recover from that. While all residue from your smoking habit should be gone inside a year,  and since you probably didn't smoke long enough to cause significant or irreversable damage, you should note improvement, but it's virtually impossible to predict by how much and in what length of time.  There are just too many variables. The more athletic you were before you quit, the less you're measureable change you're likely to see, but the longer you'll be able to do it.  2) Your blood pressure elevation (we don't have numbers, but I know what the DoD cutoff is) could have been elevated due to stress, anxiety and sleep deprivation for sure. It also could have been affected by your having been a smoker,  which, if true, will probably improve over time. You could also have an independent issue with blood pressure, but since they were able to get one acceptable reading out of three, I suspect this was a matter of circumstances and probably won't be a problem in the future. If it is, it will be something you can follow utilizing military medicine.  Hope this is helpful. Best of luck with the Marines and  your officership aspirations.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Is Hydroxycut (fat burning supplement) safe?
content: Hi there -  Hydroxycut used to contain ephedra, but was banned because of this component, which is[ b] not[/b] especially safe. However, Hydroxycut is now back on the market, and while it's safe, it's not especially effective either. It only contains caffeine as a metabolic "kick starter", much safer than ephedra, but not much more useful than having a caffeinated drink prior to exercise. You have to exercise for it to work; you're already exercising.   There's nothing that's both safe and effective that will promote an unnatural degree  of weight loss when combined with exercise.   I hope this is helpful to you. Best of luck and keep up the good work with your exercise  program.

author: Tom Plamondon PA-C  Physician Assistant Posts: 1164 Joined: Fri Oct 31, 2008 8:55 am Gender: Male
title: Re: shoulder, or back injury(muscle related i think not sure)
content: Sorry about the delayed response.  I appreciate your description of the shoulder, scapula, and surrounding muscles.    Often the shoulder complex musculature becomes out of balance.  The pects overpower the shoulder retractors.  Rarely vice versa.    The teres minor is part of the rotator cuff while the latisimus dorsi helps adduct the arm or pull the body up with the hands fixed over head.    The exercise you described should not have over worked either muscle.  Biceps curls obviously work the biceps.    What to do about this?  I would send you to an orthopedic physical therapist for a thorough stretching program and focussed strengthening regimen.  One key to rehab: strenghtening should focus on the rotator cuff and scapular thoracic muscles working in syncrony or harmony.  This requires professional supervision and instruction.    An MRI is a better test than US to find pathology of the shoulder.  (Without contrast)  Let us know how it goes.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Throw up whenever I workout
content: Hello -  You don't describe how this throwing up takes place. Do you become nauseated and feel sick, stop what you're doing and then vomit, or do you simply find that suddenly food is being regurgitated during your workout? The former would require a pretty thorough workup, as no obvious cause and effect can be inferred from it. The latter, however, could be pretty simple: an incompetent lower esophageal sphincter (LES) which allows stomach contents to be expelled when exerting, especially the abdominal muscles, or when bending at the waist (and of course, especially when doing both).   Without any additional details I would strongly suspect the latter, which may be helped by not eating for 2-3 hours before the workouts take place. Also, there are medications which can sometimes help the LES work more effectively to keep stomach contents where they belong: in the stomach.  Please let us know if this is the case or if you actually become ill when you are working out, which would be of more concern.   Good luck to you and please follow up with us.

content: Odd problem.  Was lifting heavier than normal.  A few days later I was doing some yardwork and lifted a heavy table above my head.  The next day I began to experience left  upper arm pain and pain in the front area of the shoulder where the arm meets the chest.    My bicep muscle looks like it is constantly "pumped" - like I just finished lifting weights - very odd.  Could this be bicep tendonitis? or what?
posted_time: Post  by jeffd99 » Tue Jan 22, 2008 12:31 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Odd bicep and upper arm/chest issue
content: Hello -  I am going to assume from your post that you lift weights routinely, and so are at least in that respect athletic. What you describe sounds like it could be compartment syndrome, where the connective tissue which comprises the compartments of the extremities (muscle mass, blood vessels, lymph nodes, etc.) becomes irritated and, since it is limited in its ability to stretch, can cause swelling and pain. If this resolves on its own there's no need to do more, but if it continues for more than a week or if it recurs periodically, you should see an orthopedist about it, as it can cause injury to the muscle tissue, vessels, etc., within the affected compartment.   Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (ibuprofin, naprosyn) would be your first line of relief. If the problem continues for more than a few days, do get this looked at.   Hope this is helpful.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Deltoid injury from baseball?
content: Hello -  While you probably did create some chronic irritation in the affected area as a child, and this probably did cause some permanent, minor tissue changes (even some scarring or just sensitivity), it seems if you do the reasonable things before using the arm it then responds perfectly normally, if perhaps is a little more sensitive than it would be otherwise. This is hardly surprising given the amount of overuse it saw early on. Just continue to warm up appropriately and let it rest when it starts "talking back" to you and it should be fine. Only if you were planning to resume competitive throwing on a regular basis might this pose a problem, and unless it were going to affect your career (as an athlete) should it be medically evaluated for correction at this point. Of course if it becomes chronically painful or you lose range of motion in regular activities, see an orthopedist, but otherwise, just treat it right (as you are now doing) and it would seem it responds just as one might expect.   Hope this is helpful. Good luck to you.

author: Russell3041  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Mon Feb 25, 2008 9:02 pm Gender: Male
title: Training in cold weather for a competition in warmer weather
content: How does cold weather affect breathing with regards to training and then traveling to a warmer climate and then trying to compete at peak performance?  An example would be training during December for a January 10K race.  Training would take place in Ohio, Michigan, Indiana and Illinois, then traveling to Souther California or Miami via aircraft to compete in a race a few days after arriving.  Can I expect to be able to compete fairly against the athletes from that area or will the fact that my body is acclimated to the colder weather cause me a slight disadvantage.  For instance, if I run a 5:00 mile average, how would I fair against an athlete from that area who also runs a 5 minute mile.  My feeling is that because of the cold weather, the air is denser and so your lungs will not be as strong as they need to be in the warmer weather.  Also, I would think your breaths would also be shallower to keep the lungs from experiencing pain.  Sort of like taking quick short sips of a freezing milk shake is OK but taking long hard pulls on the straw will give you what my wife calls an ice cream headache.  I would also think that the cold air will also cause me to take shorter strides as a safety against puling a muscle in the colder temps.  Thus when I go to a warmer temp, I suppose I would find my stride to be much safer against pulling a muscle but my muscles would be trained for a shorter stride which is not going to be good when racing against guys used to taking a more aggressive stride.  Any knowledge on this subject would be great.

title: Re: Training in cold weather for a competition in warmer weather
content: I would like to see some universities do very extensive studies that look at all facets of this.  I imagine that traveling to your competition, especially when time zones are crossed and when the weather is very different, etc... would have an impact on all physical aspects of your performance and also possibly on your mental alertness and concentration.  It would be very interesting to see universities spread around the nation do testing to establish a base line then travel to other locals and do more testing to see how much the traveling impacted your performance and if there is an impact, how long it takes to adjust to your new environment such that it no longer impacts your performance.

author: Russell3041  Guest Posts: 8 Joined: Mon Feb 25, 2008 9:02 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Training in cold weather for a competition in warmer weather
content: I would say that by the lack of replies, this is a subject that should seriously be studied.  I can't find anything on the net or any kind of fitness or running magazines so I am assuming that there really hasn't been a lot of research into just how much changes in environment can affect mind and body.  For instance, if a northern college plays a southern college in a bowl game and the northern team has been living in weather that is very cold, say around 0 to 20 degrees Fahrenheit and goes to Florida and plays a team from very near that area and the temps there are in the mid 60's to mid 70's does the temperature seem much hotter to the players from the north.  In other words, do their bodies react the same way the southern team's bodies would react if the temps were in the high 90's?   Also how much does travel and time zone changes affect mental acuity?  Could a dropped pass or a missed tackle, or a QB not seeing a blitz coming be attributed to the 3 times zone difference?  How much does the distance of travel affect things.   I see a great opportunity for universities around the country to work together to study this stuff.  I would think that they could use some volunteers and set up a standard physical test of running, swimming, push-ups, pull-ups, stretching, etc...Basically you would want to have you subjects meet every day and work out together.  Again I think this should be a set standard.  The same amount of running and swimming and stretching, etc... Then after a set period, you do testing to get some solid numbers for each individual.  Do the tests every day for a week.  Then you travel to other universities and do the test on the same track and pool that that university uses for it's tests.  Again you do the tests for a week.  This would allow for us to see if there is a period of time within a week where your body adjusts and returns to peak performance.   These tests could allow us to see if it is harder to go from a cold climate to a warmer climate to compete or from a warmer climate to a colder climate.  We also might be able to see if there are temps that start to become a problem and also see if the actual temp is more important or the difference in temps from home to the unfamiliar climate the competition is held in.  Humidity could also be a factor that is kept track of.  How much does humidity affect you.    To me this is a fascinating subject and I would live to see a group of universities around the country study this.  I would also think that the military and businesses could make great use of the info as well as the sports medicine field.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: HGH for growth in height
content: Hello Extasm,  Human growth hormone (HGH) is unlikely to increase your height at this point.  The reason is that your growth plates are closed.  Growth hormone has the most effect on growth before they close.  Once the growth plates close there is very little vertical growth that can occur.  At this point, there is really not much to increase your height.  Best wishes.

title: Contact sports after splenic injury?
content: I'm a 22 y/o female, I recently ruptured my spleen after being kicked in the stomach during sparring at karate.  CT scan showed a grade 3 laceration to the superior aspect of the spleen with a 7-8 cm intraparenchymal haematoma, artery and vein intact and I was managed conservatively.  My doctor has told me that my spleen is now permanently weakened due to scarring (however no follow up imaging was done) and I was advised to never engage in any contact sports again eg no rugby, hockey or contact karate ie sparring due to the ongoing risk of further injury.  I would particularly like to continue sparring at karate, I thought a foam guard of some sort would make it ok but my doctor still said no.  However after reading journal articles about conservative management of splenic injury, I have found that usually people are allowed to participate in unrestricted contact sports after 3-6 months off sports to allow for healing time, also not all cases seem to show scarring.  I have not yet found any articles with all out bans of contact sports for the rest of their lives.  Would you agree with the advice of my doctor or that of the doctors writing articles?  What is the normal long term advice given?  Is the risk of further injury high?
posted_time: Post  by truth » Mon Dec 31, 2007 8:15 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Contact sports after splenic injury?
content: Hello Truth,  The exact best recommendation for activity restriction following a splenic laceration is not fully known.  There was a good study done in 2002 looking at return to normal activity levels that showed that a restriction of 2 weeks plus the grade of the laceration was an appropriate restriction time (i.e. for a grade 3 laceration, 3 + 2 weeks = 5 weeks restriction).  This study showed that if these guidelines were followed only 1.9% of patients required hospital readmission.   A lifetime restriction may be a little aggressive; however, keep in mind that the above study was return back to NORMAL activity levels.  I was not able to find a definite guideline for strenuous contact activity such as rugby.  The risk will be higher with more intensive contact activity.  You'll need to make your own decision about this.  I suspect that your doctor is being cautious because splenic lacerations can be life threatening if severe enough.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Abdominal Pain; Which doctor?
content: Hello, I certainly understand your frustration, but you need to know that medicine is not an exact science.  It is a combination of science and art with some intuition and divine intervention thrown in at times.  Even the best doctors cannot always find the diagnosis for a problem.  Sometimes the problem must become worse before it becomes apparent.  I personally would vote for the fictional "Star Trek technique" where they waved a wand over the body and the computer told them everything they needed to know.    It is somewhat deceptive now because since we have such great technology we come to believe we have answers, if not cures, for everything.  This is far from the truth.  While we are much better and finding answers now than ever before, there is still a long way to go.    If I were you I would consult with a gastroenterologist.  You didn't say what "specialist" you have already seen.  Between this doctor and your general practitioner, you may eventually find the cause of your distress or at least learn that it is not doing any long-term harm.  Some conditions we just have to live with once we know nothing can be done to help.  But please don't judge a doctor's competence based on his or her inability to always find the right answer.  Continuing with a doctor who knows your history is a good option since they may learn more as you go along and of course they are familiar with your history.  Meanwhile, keep a diary of your experiences - exactly when this pain occurs and what makes it better or worse.  Sometimes it is purely random and coincidental; other times there will be a pattern that emerges.  Good luck

title: ankle sprain or fracture?
content: i stepped in a hole in my neighbor's yard yesterday and rolled my ankle.  there is no swelling or bruising, but it is extremely painful, more so today than it was yesterday.  the majority of the pain is on the top and sides of my foot.  should i be concerned or just ice and elevate? my medical history is as follows: 39 yr. old female history of fibromyalgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, sciatica, bursitis of hip. past surgeries are hysterectomy, ovarian cyst removal, and tonsilectomy. i am not currently on any medication.  thank you in advance for any advice you can offer.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Jadecrow,  This is a great question, one that I'm sure many of our readers also have.  Overall, the more common occurrence is to have an ankle sprain rather than a fracture; however, fractures do occur.  There is a set of criteria that we use for adults who have ankle injuries to help us decide if an x-ray is needed or if observation is an appropriate initial choice.  These are known as the Ottawa ankle rules.    They are: 1) there is point tenderness (pain in one specific spot) over either of the inner or outer prominent parts of the upper ankle bones (the medial and lateral maleolus). 2) There is point tenderness  over the bones of the top of the midfoot (the long bones of the foot). 3) There is inability to bear weight both immediately following the accident and upon evaluation.  If any of these criteria are met, an x-ray will likely be done.  These criteria are certainly not diagnostic of a fracture but are more indicative of a fracture.  If your pain is more along the joint line on the outside of the foot below the prominent bone of the ankle and above the foot (the deltoid ligament area) then the injury is more likely to be a sprain.  If your pain is improving it is likely that rest, icing, elevation and possibly a compression dressing like an ace wrap (being sure not to make it too tight) are appropriate treatments.  If your pain is not getting better or it lasts for more than 5 or 6 days without being much better you should have it checked out.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Fparley,  Hernias can cause pain similar to a pulled muscle.  Most commonly they present as a bulge in the scrotal area.  While they theoretically could cause some testicular swelling this would be pretty unlikely, unless the swelling is actually intestine in the scrotum and not enlargement of the testicle.  Hernias are typically more noticeable with standing or with bearing down of the abdominal muscles.  They typically become smaller upon lying flat.  To my knowledge there are no stretches to help determine if a hernia is present.  An ultrasound may be helpful in some cases but often is not needed.  My best recommendation for you is to follow up with your doctor for reevaluation to address your concerns.  Generally a thorough physical exam can detect a hernia.  Best wishes.

title: swelling after exercising
content: Hi! When I do any type of exercises (rollerblade, mountain walking, badminton...), I seam to get swelling or water retention in my legs.(??) By the next day, It actually looks like I've gained 2-3 pounds !? What can this be? I'm actually afraid to work out...gaining weight is definitely not the goal. Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by nadine » Mon Sep 03, 2007 9:08 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi Nadine,  Remember that water weight is not fat and it definitely temporary so don't be tempted to avoid the exercise for this reason.  Fluctuating hormone levels can contribute to water retention in women - you may even notice additional retention corresponding with your menstrual cycle.  Another factor to look at is diet.  If you use lots of sodium (salt and sodium rich foods that are typically overabundant in the American diet) this will also exacerbate the problem.  Not drinking enough water can also contribute. Add a little lemon to the water and the benefit increases.  You may also benefit from a calcium supplement.  Many women are not getting enough calcium in their diet and helping prevent fluid regulation is just one reason we want to be sure we get enough.  You may want to add around 1,000 mg. daily - dairy products can do this too in a form your body can utilize well.  If you take a supplement, the citrate is more readily absorbed than other forms such as carbonate.  Of course, water retention can also be a sign of a more serious medical condition such as kidney malfunction.  So, if the other measures don't seem to help, be sure to have this evaluated by your doctor.    Take care and congratulate yourself on your commitment to exercise.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Henry, Aggressive full-body contact sports can cause different types of injuries in the competitors.  While you may not recall a specific trauma or incident that may have caused your current neck burning and tingling, it does seem possible that a partial subluxation in the neck may have occurred either acutely or over a period of time.  Many competitors have developed a personal style of wrestling or grappling that includes favoring one side over the other, or one angle over another.  As you study your opponent prior to a match, these moves may be ones you watch for.  At the same time, you too may have developed certain habits of guarding or attack that favor certain angles.  Over a period of time the c-spine can succumb to stress or pressure and cause problems in the disks, the disk spaces, and the nerves passing through the spinal column.  A Cat Scan of the neck, maybe even an MRI would be a valuable diagnostic tool to help determine if you indeed have any damaged areas in your spinal column. I would certainly have it investigated by a physician prior to any further contact matches, to be sure you do not have something wrong right on the brink of disasterous. Your next match could be your last.

title: Working out first thing in the morning
content: Hi everyone.  I been having a problem with "waking up" in the morning.  I have no problem getting up with my alarm, but I'm very tired for most of the morning (even after drinking coffee/tea).  So, I've been thinking about working out in the morning, wondering if that will help.  I'm just interested in what the pros/cons are in working out after working out/before breakfast.  Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by SmashbrothaX » Fri Jun 24, 2005 7:50 am

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Working out in the morning is recommended after eating.  There is no ready fuel to supply energy for the body to work.  The old thinking was that since there was little to no blood sugar, it would burn fat.  Not true.  The body always burns any type of sugar it can get first, which in that case would be glycogen which is stored in the muscles.  Therefore, it burns muscle, and weaken you, the opposite of what you want!  Only when it burns the muscle free of any sugar will it burn fat.  It is best to fuel the body with "good" carbs 30-60 minutes before you exercise.  Good carbs are whole grains, whole wheat bread, plain oatmeal, no sugar (the best option) or whole grain cereal, which is the last, because there is always added sugar.  Make sure you get protein with it (2 eggs are good, or egg substitute for less cholesterol) or cottage cheese, and some juice (not from concentrate).  After a while doing this regularly (take two days off per week, your muscles need recovery time), your metabolism will move faster and burn fat.  Do not expect results right away and do not skip meals, it will slow your metabolism.  I hope that helps!

author: Jan  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Dec 20, 2004 9:22 pm Location: Colorado
title: Difficulty following exercise and insomnia
content: Hello.  I have spent the last four years practicing wellness to overcome something that is kind of like chronic fatigue.  I am much better now because I have worked hard at improving my health, but two problems remain which I have been unable to resolve.  Insomnia -- I wake up at 3 a.m. with palpitations and tension, and cannot fall back asleep for 3 hours.  Then I can sometimes sleep for a little while.  I also experience the palpitations sometimes when I am trying to fall asleep, but this is not a major issue.  Stress makes the insomnia worse.  Problems after exercising -- The last two times I did strength training (minimal - four machines for 1 minute each), about 3 hours after exercising, I became very cold, tense, and it seemed like there was some kind of spasm in my right abdomen just around or below the liver.  The energy was cut off to my upper body.  The palpitations and tension were strong.  What finally ended this episode was drinking hot herbal tea, which seemed to relax my liver. title: Weight-lifting question
content: Hey,     I've heard it's bad if you work the same muscle groups multiple days in a row and that doing so can also do more harm than good, but I've also heard of major fitness buffs who do the same workout everyday at 4 am. Thus I was wondering which is true. Will doing the same lifting exercises daily be harmful as opposed to beneficial.
posted_time: Post  by Frvade » Fri Aug 27, 2004 11:13 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Putting too much strain on a certain group of muscles will probably be counter productive. As in any training program, rest is an essential factor. It's important to leave a day between exercising a specific body part or muscle in order to reap the benefits of your hard work. Weightlifting may cause micro-tears in the muscle fiber(s) that temporarily reduce strength. These tears are thought to cause some of the soreness you feel after a new exercise or tough workout. During this crucial rest time, your muscles are building protein and getting stronger. It takes about two days to heal the muscle fibers torn by weightlifting.   One safe schedule would focus on different muscle groups in three-day cycles, leaving two days in between the same group. For example:    Day one: back and biceps  Day two: chest and triceps  Day three: legs and abs  Day four: repeat day one  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sat Aug 28, 2004 12:00 pm

author: chrisy  Guest Posts: 11 Joined: Sun Nov 02, 2003 11:39 am Location: NY
title: Stretching pain right below her knee
content: Dear Doctor,     A few days ago, my mother experience this stretching pain right below her knee. It felt like someone riped the muscle off her bone. A day later, the pain is gone but so is the muscle. it's just skin and bone. now there's a hollow. what is this strange problem? Thanks. -christina
posted_time: Post  by chrisy » Wed Jul 21, 2004 12:12 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Chrisy Its very difficult for me to evaluate your mother's problem over the internet. However, the pain you described is most often seen in muscle spasm. The muscle contracts really hard that it becomes painful. Naturally, if it contracts it becomes more prominent and your mother can easily feal it. Once it relaxes again it returns to normal and can be hardly felt unless it is contracted e.g. by flexing the toes up (dorsiflexion).  Causes of transient muscle spasm include: fatigue, mineral abnormalities and could also be a normal physiological process.
